term.longtitle: IUPAC Gold Book - Beer–Lambert law (or Beer–Lambert–Bouguer law)
term.title: Beer–Lambert law

item.text: The absorbance of a beam of collimated monochromatic radiation in a homogeneous isotropic medium is proportional to the absorption path length, l, and to the concentration, c, or — in the gas phase — to the pressure of the absorbing species. The law can be expressed as: A = log10(Pλ0/Pλ) = ɛcl, is called the molar (decadic) absorption coefficient. For cm and mol dm-3 or M, dm^3 mol^-1 cm^-1 or M^-1 cm^-1, which is a commonly used unit. The SI unit of m2 mol-1. Note that spectral radiant power must be used because the Beer–Lambert law holds only if the spectral bandwidth of the light is narrow compared to spectral linewidths in the spectrum.

item.meaning: per moles per liter (as M) per cm
